Comment: Welcome to /r/ask_politics.  Our goal here is to provide educated, informed, and serious answers to questions about the world of politics.  Our full [rules](https://www.reddit.com/r/Ask_Politics/wiki/rules) can be found here, but are summarized below.  * Address the question (and its replies) in a professional manner * Avoid personal attacks and partisan "point scoring" * Avoid the use of partisan slang and [fallacies](https://www.wikiwand.com/en/List_of_fallacies) * Provide sources if possible at the time of commenting.  **If asked, you must provide sources.** * Help avoid the echo chamber - downvote bad/poorly sourced responses, not responses you disagree with.  **Do not downvote just because you disagree with the response**. * Report any comments that do not meet our standards and rules. Comment: He would remain a Senator. He would leave the GOP caucus in the Senate and join the Democratic caucus in the Senate. He would also need to switch financial support from the RNC to the DNC.   But senators have swapped parties before with little to no fanfare.
Author: ProLifePanda

Comment: Belonging to a party has no legal relationship with your seat as Senator. Someone could get elected belonging to any, or no party, and could change or leave any party at any time. It isn't typically done because being a flip-flopper is often really bad for your image.  There are cases, such as the case with Tulsi Gabbard, where she was detached from the democratic party's majority values for many years before announcing that she was leaving it. In this case the optics were not as bad, as her values did not appear to change.
Author: yaya-pops
